facts.text: The respondent, Daulatram Rawatmal, is a firm registered under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. The respondent, Daulatram Rawatmal, is a firm registered under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: The firm had six partners: Nandlal Bhowalka, Giridharilal Bhowalka, Shyamlal Bhowalka, Bajranlal Bhowalka, Rawatmal Nopany and Rameshwarlal Nopany.

anchor.surface_text: . At all material times there were six partners of the firm. They were Nandlal Bhowalka, Giridharilal Bhowalka, Shyamlal Bhowalka, Bajranlal Bhowalka, Rawatmal Nopany and Rameshwarlal Nopany.

facts.text: The firm carried on business as dealers and commission agents in jute, rice and other commodities.

anchor.surface_text: The firm carried on business as dealers and companymission agents in jute, rice and other companymodities.

facts.text: Accounting year 2001-2002 Bikram Samvat from September 27, 1944, to October 15, 1945, assessed in assessment year 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: For the account year 2001-2002 Bikram Samvat  September 27, 1944, to October 15, 1945  the firm was assessed in the assessment year 1946-47 by the Income-tax Officer Non - Companies - cum - E. P. T. Circle

facts.text: The firm was assessed by the Income-tax Officer Non-Companies-cum-E.P.T. Circle under section 23(3) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: by the Income-tax Officer Non - Companies - cum - E. P. T. Circle, under section 23 3  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: On February 19, 1955, the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI issued a notice under section 34 calling for revised return.

anchor.surface_text: On February 19,1955, the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, to whom the case was transferred by the Central Board of Revenue, issued a numberice under section 34 of the Act calling upon the firm to file a revised return of income

facts.text: The firm filed a revised return showing income of Rs. 2,75,168.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this numberice the firm filed a return showing an income of Rs. 2,75,168 according to its original assessment as reduced in appeal.

facts.text: On November 2, 1944, Rs. 5,00,000 was tendered in cash to Barabazar Branch of Central Bank of India, transferred to Bombay head office, demand draft issued to Jamnagar branch.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer thereafter inspected the books of account of the assessee and found that on November 2,1944, an amount of Rs. 5,00,000 was tendered in cash to the Barabazar Branch of the Central Bank of India with instruction to transfer the same to the Bombay head office of the bank and a demand draft for the said amount was issued through the Bombay head office of the bank on its Jamnagar branch

facts.text: Fixed deposit receipt purchased on November 8, 1944, in name of Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla, son of Rawatmul Nopany, with Jamnagar branch.

anchor.surface_text: , which was at the material time situate in the territory of the Indian State of Nawanagar. Out of the remittance a fixed deposit receipt was purchased in the name of Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla, son of Rawatmul Nopany, with the Jamnagar branch of the Central Bank of India on November 8, 1944.

facts.text: Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla died on August 16, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: this Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla died on August 16, 1945, and the fixed deposit receipt matured on December 19,1945.

facts.text: Fixed deposit matured on December 19, 1945, sum of Rs. 5,00,000 paid to heirs but adjusted against overdraft of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Upon maturity the sum of Rs. 5,00,000 was number paid to the heirs of Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla, but it was adjusted against the over draft of the assessee.

facts.text: Assessee's books showed credit of Rs. 5,00,000 in account of Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla, balance Rs. 5,64,970 carried forward to next year, account continued after death.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees books account showed a credit of Rs. 5,00,000 in the account of Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla. The account of Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla in the assessees books showed a current account involving large sums of money and the balance of Rs. 5,64,970 was carried forward to the next year. Although Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla had died in August, 1945, the account companytinued in the same name in the next year.

facts.text: On November 15, 1944, Rs. 5,00,000 tendered in cash to Barabazar branch, demand draft to B. N. Gupta, son of Bajranglal Bhowalka, fixed deposit on November 21, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer also found that on November 15,1944, another amount of Rs. 5,00,000 was tendered in cash in the Barabazar branch of the Central Bank of the Central Bank of India with instructions to transfer the same to the Bombay head office of the bank and a demand draft was issued from Bombay in the name of B. N. Gupta, son of Bajranglal Bhowalka - a partner of the assessee - on the Jamnagar branch of the bank and that with the aid of this amount a fixed deposit account was opened with the Central Bank of India, Jamnagar, on November 21,1944.

facts.text: On December 2, 1944, letter of guarantee and continuity signed by Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla and B. N. Gupta, promissory notes by firm for overdraft facilities of Rs. 10,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: On December 2,1944, a letter of guarantee and a letter of companytinuity signed by Raghunath Prasad Agarwalla and B. N. Gupta along with promissory numberes signed by the firm for keeping these two deposits under lien were lodged with the bank for securing over draft facilities for the assessee in the sum of Rs. 10,00,000.

facts.text: On October 5, 1944, Rs. 5,00,000 tendered in cash to Barabazar branch, remitted to Jamnagar for fixed deposit dated October 11, 1944, in name of Sheo Prasad Agarwalla, son of Rameshwarlal Nopany.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer also found that an amount of Rs. 5,00,000 was tendered in cash in the Barabazar branch of the Central Bank of India on October 5,1944, with instructions to remit the same to the Jamnagar branch by a demand draft to be companyverted into a fixed deposit dated October 11,1944, in the name of Sheo Prasad Agarwalla, Son of Rameshwarlal Nopany -a partner of the assessee.

facts.text: The deposit of Sheo Prasad Agarwalla was offered as security for overdraft to Sri Hanuman Sugar Mills Ltd., in which partners of assessee had controlling interest.

anchor.surface_text: This deposit was later offered as security for overdraft facility granted to Sri Hanuman Sugar Mills Ltd., in the managing agency of which the partners of the assessee had a companytrolling interest.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer added Rs. 15,00,000 as secreted profits to assessee's income and completed reassessment.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the income-tax officer the amounts of the fixed deposits receipts credited in the Jamnagar branch of the Central Bank of India in the names of the three sons of the partners of the assessee were secreted profits belonging to the assessee and on that view he added the sum of Rs. 15,00,000 to its total assessable income and companypleted the reassessment.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner in appeal added Rs. 14,50,000 as secreted profits, allowing explanation for Rs. 50,000 in B. N. Gupta deposit.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the assessee the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax held that the assessee was able to explain the source of Rs. 50,000 only, out of the fixed deposit of Rs. 5,00,000 in the account of B. N. Gupta, but number in respect of the other deposits. Accordingly the Appellate Assistant Commissioner modified the order of the Income-tax Officer and added an amount of Rs. 14,50,000

facts.text: Tribunal confirmed addition for deposits of Raghunath Prasad and B. N. Gupta but excluded Rs. 5,00,000 of Sheo Prasad Agarwalla due to no connecting link.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was companyfirmed in appeal, in so far as it related to the two deposit receipts dated November 8, 1944, and November 21, 1944. But in respect of the receipt dated october 11, 1944, the Tribunal held that even though a similar modus was adopted... no connecting link... excluded from total assessable income.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax applied under section 66(1) for reference to High Court, rejected by Tribunal as question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax applied under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal to refer to the High Court of Calcutta the following question... The Tribunal rejected the application observing that the question... was a question of fact number referable under section 66 1

facts.text: Commissioner applied to High Court of Calcutta for reference, application rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax then applied to the High Court of Calcutta for an order calling upon the Tribunal to state a case and refer it to the High Court. The High Court rejected the application.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this companyrt.

facts.text: Three partners of assessee were directors of Sri Hanuman Sugar Mills Ltd., and the firm had controlling interest.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee had denied companynection with Sri Hanuman Sugar Mills Ltd., but the record disclosed that a large amount exceeding Rs. 8,00,000 was advanced to Hanuman Investment Ltd. - managing agents of the Sugar Mills Ltd., - and the entire amount so advanced had ultimately found its way into the account of the sugar mills. Out of the six partners of the assessee three were directors of Sri Hanuman Sugar Mills Ltd.,

facts.text: Jamnagar branch was in territory of Indian State of Nawanagar at material time.

anchor.surface_text: a demand draft for the said amount was issued through the Bombay head office of the bank on its Jamnagar branch, which was at the material time situate in the territory of the Indian State of Nawanagar.

holdings.text: Findings on questions of pure fact arrived at by the Tribunal are not to be disturbed by the High Court on a reference unless it appears that there was no evidence before the Tribunal upon which they, as reasonable men, could have reached those findings.

anchor.surface_text: In Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. V. Commissioner of Income-tax this court held that findings on questions of pure fact arrived at by the Tribunal are not to be disturbed by the High Court on a references unless it appears that there was no evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent from Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd.; Tribunal findings final if supported by evidence.

holdings.text: When the point for determination is a pure question of law such as construction of a statute or document of title, the decision of the Tribunal is open to reference to the court under section 66(1).

anchor.surface_text: When the point for determination is a pure question of law such as construction of a statute or document of title, the decision of the Tribunal is open to reference to the court under section 66 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principles governing references under s.66(1); distinguishes pure law questions as referable.

holdings.text: When the point for determination is a mixed question of law and fact, while the finding of the Tribunal on the facts found is final, its decision as to the legal effect of those findings is a question of law which can be reviewed by the court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes mixed questions; facts final, legal effect reviewable as law.

holdings.text: A finding on a question of fact is open to attack under section 66(1) as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Perversity or lack of evidence elevates fact finding to question of law.

holdings.text: The High Court exercises an advisory jurisdiction under section 66 and has no power to call upon the Tribunal to state a case if there is some evidence to support the finding recorded by the Tribunal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits HC jurisdiction to questions of law; cannot re-appraise evidence if supported.

holdings.text: The conclusion recorded by the Tribunal that the fixed deposit of Rs. 5,00,000 in the name of Sheo Prasad Agarwalla did not represent secreted profits of the assessee is not perverse.

precedents.case_name: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: principles which govern references under section 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act are well settled. findings on questions of pure fact arrived at by the Tribunal are not to be disturbed by the High Court on a reference unless it appears that there was no evidence before the Tribunal upon which they, as reasonable men, could have reached those findings. This is so even if the High Court left to itself would on the evidence have reached a conclusion different from that of the Tribunal. The rules which govern the approach of the High Court are [listed rules on pure law, mixed law and fact, perverse findings, inferences from facts].
precedents.cited_holding: findings on questions of pure fact arrived at by the Tribunal are not to be disturbed by the High Court on a reference unless it appears that there was no evidence before the Tribunal upon which they, as reasonable men, could have reached those findings.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said that the conclusion recorded by the Tribunal on the facts brought to our numberice by Mr. Sastri is perverse. The Tribunal has rightly pointed out that the similarity of the transactions in respect of the three deposit receipt and the proximity of time were matters which may raise suspicion and this suspicions may be strengthened because Sri Hanuman Sugar Mills Ltd. was the ultimate beneficiary of the amount deposited on October II, 1944, and the deposit was apparently obtained in the name of Sheo Prasad Agarwalla benami for the real owner.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal by Commissioner dismissed; Tribunal's finding excluding Rs. 5,00,000 deposit in name of Sheo Prasad Agarwalla from assessee's secreted profits upheld as not perverse and supported by evidence
